qas.question: What gives bipolar transistors their name?

answers.text: they conduct by using both majority and minority carriers

qas.question: What was the first mass-produced transistor?
What is the bipolar junction transistor a combination of?
What is the name for a layer of p-type semiconductor set between two n-type semiconductors?
What is the name for a layer of n-type semiconductor set between two p-type semiconductors?
What kind of transistor is used the most?
Where do junction diodes get their name?
What is the most common type of bipolar transistor?
How are bipolar transistors mass produced?

context: <b5_0>Bipolar transistors<b5_0/> are so named because <a0_0>they conduct by using both majority and minority carriers<a0_0/>. The <a1_0>bipolar junction transistor<a1_0/>, the first type of transistor to be mass-produced, is a combination of <a2_0>two junction diodes<a2_0/>, and is formed of either a thin layer of p-type semiconductor <b6_0>sandwiched between two n-type semiconductors<b6_0/> (<b7_0>an <a3_0>n–p–n transistor<b7_0/><a3_0/>), or a thin layer of n-type semiconductor sandwiched between two p-type semiconductors (a <a4_0>p–n–p transistor<a4_0/>). This construction produces two p–n junctions: a base–emitter junction and a base–collector junction, separated by a thin region of semiconductor known as the base region (two junction diodes <b8_0>wired together<b8_0/> without sharing an intervening semiconducting region will not make a transistor).
